Award.AwardTitle: Strategies: Water SCIENCE: Supporting Collaborative Inquiry, Engineering, and Career Exploration with Water

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
As part of an overall strategy to develop understandings of best practice factors, contexts and processes contributing to K-12 students' motivation and participation in STEM, the ITEST Program funds foundational and applied research projects that build student awareness of STEM and STEM-related careers. This ITEST Strategies project, Supporting Collaborative Inquiry, Engineering, and Career Exploration with Water (Water SCIENCE), engages middle school students in project-based learning around their community's water resources. Through the innovative use of technology the project enables data sharing among schools in different parts of the country and provides a forum for the development of a professional learning community for teachers. The project turns tablet computers now found in secondary schools into mobile science labs, harnessing the built-in cameras for chemical and visual analysis of water samples.

A total of 30 middle school science teachers from diverse districts in southern Arizona, southeastern Pennsylvania, and Eastern Massachusetts are participating serving more than 2000 middle school students over the three-year project. Students will use an innovative mobile lab to perform water quality analysis and aggregate the results on an existing data sharing platform. In consultation with university mentors and stem professionals, students design and conduct classroom engineering projects that model real-world technologies for improving water quality. Virtual mentoring sessions provide opportunities for students to ask questions of STEM professionals and learn about careers in environmental science and conservation. As a culminating experience students engage in a role-playing exercise involving a simulated water emergency. Teachers will receive over 40 hours of professional development as well as a classroom set of hands-on science and engineering materials undergraduate and graduate students will participate as mentors.

A systematic investigation of the impact of integrating purposefully designed inquiry, engineering, and career orientation activities into science instruction at the middle school level will be conducted. Student outcomes explored include stem career awareness and interests, stem content knowledge, and the development of supportive mentoring relationships with university students and stem professionals. Comprehensive data will be collected using a variety of research instruments and analyzed both statistically and qualitatively.

This project team is comprised of specialists in K-12 curriculum and educational technology development (Concord Consortium), environmental sustainability (Arizona State University), freshwater science and conservation (Stroud Water Resource Center), and hands-on engineering education (Machine Science, Inc.). The Water SCIENCE project helps advance NSF's goal of broadening participation and diversifying the STEM workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supporting Collaborative Inquiry, Engineering, and Career Exploration with Water (Water SCIENCE) was an ITEST Strategies project (http://stemforall2017.videohall.com/presentations/909) that engaged middle school students in project-based learning about water-related STEM topics and STEM careers. Participating students studied their community’s water resources, completed engineering projects, worked side by side with undergraduate and graduate student mentors, and shared water science data online with other participating students across the country. The project team brought together specialists in K-12 curriculum and educational technology development from the Concord Consortium and Machine Science, an environmental sustainability specialist from Central Valley California and Arizona State University, freshwater scientists and conservationists from Stroud Water Resource Center, and hands-on engineering educators from Machine Science, Inc.

The goals of the Water SCIENCE project were to have students take a stronger interest in water-related STEM careers (https://guides.itsi.concord.org/water-science-teacher-guides#water-scientist-videos), boost their STEM content knowledge, and develop a sense of connection to a community of university students and STEM professionals.

Water SCIENCE offered a unique curriculum (https://itsi.portal.concord.org/itsi#middle-school-environmental-science), aligned to the National Science Education Standards and the Next Generation Science Standards, by incorporating inquiry, engineering, and STEM career orientation into middle school science instruction. Students used an innovative mobile app and online portal to record and distribute water quality analyses and aggregate the results on an existing data-sharing platform. In consultation with university mentors and STEM professionals, students designed and conducted classroom engineering projects that modeled real-world technologies for improving water quality.

The project employed innovative technologies to enable data sharing among schools in different parts of the country. By utilizing an open-source data-sharing platform, the Internet System for Networked Science Experimentation (iSENSE), students from different geographic regions could compare their results. The Concord Consortium’s Innovative Technology for Science Inquiry (ITSI) portal provided a platform for students and teachers to document activities and build supportive networking relationships. 

A total of 30 middle school science teachers from diverse districts in arid Central Valley California and southern Arizona, rural agricultural southeastern Pennsylvania, and eastern coastal Massachusetts participated, serving a total of more than 2,000 middle school students over the course of the project. Classrooms had additional support from undergraduate and graduate student mentors. The capstone activity provided classrooms across the country the ability to communicate with each other, share their data, and compare their water quality to understand that not everyone has the same experience with their local watershed.

Several features of the Water SCIENCE project expand its impact beyond the educators and students directly served. All classroom activities, water quality data, and virtual mentoring sessions are archived online as resources for middle school educators. In addition, the Water SCIENCE project helped advance NSF’s goal of diversifying the STEM workforce. The participating school districts served racially diverse, low-income student populations, 40% to 80% of whom identify as Latino(a) and 36% to 89% of whom qualify for free or reduced-price lunch.
